BB is the midpoint of the hypotenuse MNMN of an isosceles right-triangle prism.
The hypotenuse is at 45∘ and its midpoint B(L/2,L/2) is the point where the light first leaves the prism.
The semicylinder’s centre O lies on the line through B perpendicular to the hypotenuse; C must lie somewhere on that same hypotenuse, inside the semicircle.
The semicylinder’s refractive index is nh = 2410/30 ≈ 1.636.
Once the incidence and refraction angles at B and C are known, Snell’s law will give the prism’s index np.
One geometrical datum is still missing: we are not told exactly where the hypotenuse cuts the semicircle, i.e. where the point C is chosen along the line MN.
Different choices of C (all consistent with |OC|=3R/4) give different interior refraction angles and therefore different values of the prism’s index np.
A single extra piece of information would be enough – for example, the length of the hypotenuse MN, or the height MC, or the horizontal distance CQ in the diagram.
Without that the refractive index of the glass prism cannot be determined uniquely.
